52. The Overthrow of Tsarism in February 1917.
Uprising in Petrograd . Tsar Nicholas II and his ministers were at a loss as to how to cope with the defeat at the front and the impending revolution. They were at a loss for what to do. Even the bourgeois "Cadet" party and its leader, Miliukov, ceased supporting the Tsar due to defeats at the front; but the Cadets also feared revolution. The bourgeoisie decided to remove Nicholas II from power and install his brother Mikhail on the throne, suppress the nascent revolutionary movement, and continue the war. Those close to the Tsar advised Nicholas II to end the war, conclude a separate peace with the Germans, and then deal with the revolution. The plans of the Tsar and the bourgeoisie did not come to fruition. They were forestalled by an uprising of workers and soldiers, which began in February 1917. In early 1917, the starving and war-weary workers of Petrograd went on strike. The Bolsheviks led the workers' struggle. They also infiltrated soldiers' barracks, calling on the army to support the workers in their fight against the Tsar. Working men and women took to the streets and demanded: "Down with the war!" Down with the tsarist government! Bread! Peace! Soon the workers began to understand that the tsarist government could not be defeated by a single strike; an armed uprising was necessary—and they rebelled. The tsarist ministers gave the order to shoot the workers without mercy. In the city center, police set up machine guns on rooftops and in attics and fired at the demonstrators. The heroic struggle of the Petrograd workers also drew soldiers into the revolution. On February 27, the troops in Petrograd refused to fire on the workers and began to go over to the side of the people. The rebellious workers and soldiers arrested the tsarist ministers and imprisoned them. Imprisoned revolutionaries were released from prison. Crowds burned police and courthouses. Young workers and working women participated in the uprising alongside their brothers and husbands. Tsar Nicholas II, who was outside Petrograd at the time, sent troops from the front against the rebellious people. But revolutionary workers and soldiers rode out to meet them, explained what they were fighting for, and convinced the troops to disobey the orders of the tsar and the generals. The soldiers obeyed the workers. The revolution triumphed over the tsarist regime. When news of the revolution's victory in Petrograd reached other cities and the front, workers and soldiers overthrew the tsarist regime locally as well. Following the example of the first revolution of 1905, Soviets were created everywhere, but these were no longer just Soviets of workers' deputies, but Soviets of workers' and soldiers' deputies. This marked the difference between the February Revolution of 1917 and the revolution of 1905. The soldiers' deputies in the Soviets were, in essence, peasant deputies, disguised in soldiers' uniforms for the occasion. This meant that the Soviets of workers' and soldiers' deputies were, in fact, Soviets of workers' and peasants' deputies. This meant that an alliance of workers and peasants against the tsarist regime had already formed, and the Soviets of workers' and soldiers' deputies became the organs of this alliance. Without this alliance, the people could not have overthrown the tsar, and the revolution could not have triumphed. Two powers. The bourgeoisie managed to exploit the petty-bourgeois politicians, the Mensheviks and Socialist Revolutionaries, who constituted the majority in the Soviets, and with their help seized power in the country. Traitors to the revolution—the Mensheviks and Socialist Revolutionaries—enabled the bourgeoisie to establish their own bourgeois Provisional Government. But the Soviets continued to exist alongside the Provisional Government. Two powers emerged in the country.
Upon arriving in Petrograd on April 3, 1917, the leader of the proletariat, V. I. Lenin, was greeted by revolutionary sailors and soldiers.
The bourgeoisie and the Mensheviks and Socialist Revolutionaries entrenched in the Soviets sought to continue the war with Germany to a victorious end. The land remained in the hands of the landowners. Capitalists continued to rob the workers. The oppression of the peoples of Russia remained. Lenin, in letters from abroad, and the Bolsheviks, led by Comrade Stalin, who had returned from exile, denounced the Provisional Government to the people and exposed the deceptions of the Mensheviks and Socialist Revolutionaries. On April 3, 1917, Lenin returned to Russia with great difficulty from abroad. All of revolutionary Petrograd —workers, sailors, and soldiers—gathered to greet him. The cheers for Lenin were endless. Lenin climbed onto an armored car, spoke to the people, and into the hushed crowd he issued a fiery appeal: "Long live the world socialist revolution!" It was a call to fight against the bourgeois Provisional Government, to establish working-class power, and to fight for socialism.
XII. The Great October Socialist Revolution in Russia
53. The Bolsheviks Prepare the Socialist Revolution
. The masses follow the Bolsheviks. Upon Lenin's arrival, the party convened a conference of Bolsheviks. Delegates representing 80,000 party members from all over Russia converged on Petrograd . Molotov, Voroshilov, Sverdlov, Kuibyshev, Dzerzhinsky, and many others attended the conference. Lenin and Stalin presided over the conference. They pointed out that the working class had accomplished only its first task—the abolition of the tsarist autocracy in Russia. They said a second task still needed to be accomplished—the socialist revolution. They said the party still faced a serious and arduous struggle, because the bourgeoisie, which had come to dominate the country, would not relinquish power without fierce resistance. They called on the party to win a majority in the Soviets of Workers' and Soldiers' Deputies, as well as in the Soviets of Peasants' Deputies, and to expel the Mensheviks and Socialist Revolutionaries from them. Lenin and Stalin called on the Bolsheviks to organize the masses to fight for the socialist revolution. For the socialist revolution to succeed, they argued, the working class, in close alliance with the poor peasantry, must overthrow the rule of the bourgeoisie. It was necessary to curb the bourgeoisie, wrest the land from the landowners and give it to the peasants for use, grant freedom to the oppressed peoples of Russia, and immediately end the war.
The peasants demanded land. A fellow sailor called for the immediate, organized seizure of the landowners' lands.
Lenin and Stalin's proposals were accepted by the conference. The Bolsheviks launched a massive campaign among the workers, soldiers, and sailors. They also launched a campaign among the peasants. They explained the conference's decisions and called on the people to fight against the Provisional Government for the establishment of Soviet power, an end to the war, and the immediate transfer of all land to the peasants. Workers' and soldiers' demonstrations began in Petrograd . In April, a demonstration of workers and soldiers was organized. The demonstrators carried placards and banners with Bolshevik slogans: "Down with the war! " "Down with the capitalist ministers! " "All power to the Soviets!" The Provisional Government, together with the Mensheviks and Socialist Revolutionaries, was forced to remove the most hated capitalist ministers, Guchkov and Milyukov, from their posts and included several Mensheviks and Socialist Revolutionaries in its ranks. But the government's policies remained unchanged. The war continued, landowners controlled the land, oppressed peoples remained disenfranchised, and workers were threatened with lockouts (the closure of enterprises). The revolutionary mood of the masses grew. They increasingly listened to the voice of the Bolsheviks. The Bolshevik Party grew stronger. In early June 1917, the First All-Russian Congress of Soviets of Workers' and Soldiers' Deputies was held in Petrograd . At this congress, the Mensheviks and Socialist Revolutionaries still held a majority. They secured the congress's approval for support of the bourgeois government and an offensive at the front. The offensive at the front began then. It ended in defeat for the Russian army. The soldiers were reluctant to go into battle, refusing to fight for the interests of the bourgeoisie and demanding the transfer of all power to the Soviets. In vain did the Provisional Government's Minister of War, the Socialist Revolutionary Kerensky, try to persuade the soldiers to shed their blood for a cause alien to them. "The bourgeoisie needs the war," the soldiers replied, "let them fight themselves." The Provisional Government ordered the execution of soldiers who refused to go into battle. The soldiers became increasingly convinced of the betrayal of their interests by the Mensheviks and Socialist Revolutionaries and defected to the Bolsheviks. Demonstrations of workers and soldiers began again in Russia's major cities. The July demonstration and the mutiny of General Kornilov. The summer of 1917 arrived. The Provisional Government still had not satisfied a single demand of the workers, soldiers, peasants, and oppressed peoples of Russia. The devastation in industry and on the railways intensified. Factories and plants were shut down, there were no raw materials or fuel. There was a shortage of bread and meat. Famine was looming. The workers' struggle against the capitalists and their government intensified. Strikes were continuous. Workers organized their own armed units—the Red Guard. Peasant uprisings broke out in the villages. Soldiers left the front in the thousands. Oppressed peoples, denied liberation by the Provisional Government, came forward with their just demands. On July 3, 1917, masses of Petrograd workers, soldiers, and sailors demonstrated under Bolshevik slogans. The bourgeoisie, in collusion with the Mensheviks and Socialist Revolutionaries, called in elite cadet and kulak military units from the front and executed the demonstration, smashing workers' organizations.
Shooting of the demonstration on July 3, 1917, in Petrograd .
Cadets and officers attacked the editorial office of the newspaper Pravda. Bolsheviks were arrested and imprisoned. The Bolsheviks were forced to go underground again. The Provisional Government ordered Lenin's arrest. At the insistence of the Party, Lenin went into hiding. Lenin disguised himself as a worker and, with a passport in the name of a worker named Ivanov, lived in a hut on the outskirts of Petrograd , near Sestroretsk, and some time later moved to Finland. Bourgeois bloodhounds hunted Lenin in vain. The workers protected their beloved leader by all means. The bourgeoisie raged in the rear and at the front. Even the most backward workers began to understand the consequences of the Mensheviks and Socialist Revolutionaries, who defended the interests of the bourgeoisie. More and more workers joined the ranks of the Bolsheviks. The membership of the Bolshevik Party increased to 200,000. At the end of July, the Sixth Congress of the Bolshevik Party convened in Petrograd . Lenin was not present at the congress. He was in hiding. Stalin led the congress. He called on the party to prepare for an armed uprising. The congress outlined the path to victory for the socialist revolution and developed measures to combat the economic devastation in the country. Delegates scattered across Russia began preparing workers and poor peasants for an uprising against the Provisional Government, to overthrow its authority, and to establish the power of the Soviets, the power of workers and peasants. Then the bourgeoisie and landowners organized a conspiracy against the revolution. On their instructions, General Kornilov assembled large detachments of officers, Cossacks, and backward troops and marched them on Petrograd to smash the Soviets of Workers' and Soldiers' Deputies, strangle the workers and peasants, and declare himself the absolute ruler of Russia. At the call of the Bolsheviks, the workers of Petrograd and the Petrograd troops rose up. Revolutionary agitators—workers and soldiers—sent to meet Kornilov's troops told Kornilov's soldiers of their general's true intentions. The soldiers of Kornilov's regiments refused to oppose the revolution. The bourgeoisie's conspiracy failed. Under pressure from the workers and peasants, Kerensky was forced to arrest Kornilov and imprison him. The workers' and soldiers' victory over Kornilov further strengthened the Bolshevik Party's influence. After the Kornilov rebellion, workers and soldiers began expelling the Mensheviks and Socialist Revolutionaries from the Soviets and electing Bolsheviks in their place. In the fall of 1917, the majority of the Petrograd and Moscow Soviets went over to the Bolsheviks. The Soviets became the true centers of the proletarian revolution. They armed the workers, created the Red Guard, and prepared for an armed uprising. In early October, Lenin, hiding from the bourgeois government, appeared in Petrograd to lead the uprising. Lenin declared that the workers' victory was now assured, that an armed uprising must be launched immediately, the government of the bourgeoisie, the Mensheviks, and the Socialist Revolutionaries must be overthrown, and the power of the Soviets must be established.
54. The socialist revolution triumphed.
The victorious uprising of October 25 (November 7), 1917. The Bolshevik Party was preparing for the final, decisive battle—the overthrow of bourgeois power by force of arms. The moment for the uprising was well chosen. The world war continued. In Russia, the majority of workers followed the Bolsheviks. The compromising Menshevik and Socialist-Revolutionary parties had lost the trust of the working people. Many Soviets of Workers' and Soldiers' Deputies were in Bolshevik hands. The workers had their own strong trade unions and the Red Guard. The peasants did not want to wait for the convocation of the Constituent Assembly, as the compromising Socialist-Revolutionary and Menshevik parties advised them to do, and followed the Bolsheviks, who demanded the immediate seizure of the landowners' lands. They expelled the landowners from their namedays and seized the land. The soldiers did not want to continue the war. They rejected Kerensky's order to fight to the bitter end and demanded peace. Not only Russian workers and peasants, but also the peoples of Transcaucasia, Ukraine, Belarus, Central Asia, and Finland rose up against Kerensky's Provisional Government. The Bolsheviks vigorously prepared for the uprising. Its plan was carefully developed.
V. I. Lenin (1870–1924)
Lenin and Stalin among the Red Guards.
But in the most decisive days of preparation for the uprising, Kamenev, Zinoviev, and Trotsky betrayed the plans and dates of the uprising to the bourgeoisie. The Provisional Government, having learned of the uprising from traitors, urgently mobilized troops loyal to it to fight it. But the days of bourgeois rule were numbered. The Central Committee of the Bolshevik Party created a combat center to lead the uprising, headed by Comrade Stalin. Following Lenin's instructions, on October 24, 1917, the combat center launched the uprising. Lenin stood at its head.
V. I. Lenin leads the uprising in the October days of 1917.
As one, the Red Guards, revolutionary soldiers, and sailors of Kronstadt rose up in response to the call of the Bolshevik Party. The courage, revolutionary drive, and discipline of the revolutionary soldiers quickly did their job. All government institutions and military posts in Petrograd were occupied by the Red Guards. The ministers of the Provisional Government, along with detachments of officers and cadets, fortified themselves in the Winter Palace. On October 25, revolutionary troops surrounded the palace. The revolutionary cruiser Aurora and three destroyers entered the Neva River. The siege of the palace lasted until evening. Darkness fell. Only the enormous Winter Palace remained illuminated. Toward nightfall, the fighting intensified. Machine guns rattled. Rifle volleys rang out. A firefight broke out between the troops entrenched in the palace and the advancing revolutionaries. The Red Guards began their assault on the palace.
Revolutionary sailors storm the Winter Palace in October 1917.
The Bolsheviks, who had led the capture of the Winter Palace, offered the besieged forces the opportunity to surrender. They refused. The signal was given. The cannons of the Peter and Paul Fortress opened fire on the Winter Palace. The guns of the cruiser Aurora roared. The artillery fire had its effect. The machine guns in the palace fell silent. The revolutionary troops stormed the palace. The officers and cadets continued to fire back, but soon they surrendered. The Red Guards entered the palace's circular room through a narrow corridor. Several frightened people sat at tables. This was the last bourgeois government in Russia. Kerensky was not there, having managed to escape and hide. In the name of the revolution, all the ministers were declared under arrest. Those arrested were taken to the fortress. The proletarian revolution had triumphed throughout the country. The working class celebrated its victory. On October 25, the people of Petrograd read Lenin's proclamation with profound emotion. It declared that the Provisional Government had fallen, and power had passed into the hands of the Soviets of Workers' and Soldiers' Deputies. The cause for which the people had fought—ending the war, abolishing landlord ownership of land, and establishing a Soviet government—was assured. It was now possible to establish workers' control over factories and plants to combat economic devastation. The Second All-Russian Congress of Soviets of Workers' and Soldiers' Deputies opened at the same time. Lenin submitted, and the congress approved, the first three decrees of the Great Proletarian Revolution: on peace, on land, and on power. The Decree on Peace proposed that all belligerent states immediately begin negotiations to end the war and conclude a peace on the basis of equality. The Decree on Land abolished the landlord class, abolished private landownership, and transferred it to the use of all working people. Peasants received over 150 million hectares of land from the Soviet government. The Decree on Power transferred all power in the country to the Soviets. Our country became a Soviet Republic. The Congress elected the All-Russian Central Executive Committee and the Council of People's Commissars. V. I. Lenin became the head of the Council of People's Commissars. Comrade Stalin was elected People's Commissar for Nationalities. Soon after the Congress, Comrade Sverdlov was elected Chairman of the All-Russian Central Executive Committee. News of the proletariat's victory in Petrograd quickly spread throughout the country. In a number of cities, workers had to wage fierce battles to seize power.
Yakov Mikhailovich Sverdlov (1885–1919).
In Moscow, officers and cadets seized the Kremlin and a number of large buildings. Red Guard workers were forced to dig trenches and wage a real war against counterrevolutionaries. Fighting raged in Moscow for a whole week. Only with cannon fire did the workers and soldiers force the officers and cadets to surrender. Telegrams about the transfer of power to the Soviets flew from all Russian cities to Petrograd . The peoples of Siberia, Central Asia, Belarus, the Volga region, and the left bank of Ukraine, with the help of the Soviet government, were liberating themselves from centuries-old oppression by the bourgeoisie and landowners.
The capture of the Kremlin by insurgent workers in Moscow in the October days of 1917.
The victory of the socialist Soviet revolution is thus explained by the following reasons: 1) The bourgeois government of the Socialist Revolutionary Kerensky had completely failed in the eyes of the workers and peasants. Kerensky sought to continue the war to a victorious conclusion, while the workers, peasants, and soldiers demanded an end to the war and the conclusion of peace. Kerensky sought to preserve the lands for the landowners, while the workers and peasants demanded the immediate seizure of the landowners' lands for the peasants. Kerensky sought to curb the workers, while the workers and peasants demanded the curbing of factory owners and the establishment of workers' organizations over them. 2) The second reason is that, on the basis of these demands, a strong alliance of workers and peasants was formed and consolidated in the form of the Sonnets of Workers' and Soldiers' Deputies against the bourgeois Provisional Government and its lackeys—the Socialist Revolutionaries and Mensheviks—in support of the Bolshevik Party. 3) The third reason is that the workers and peasants en masse abandoned the compromising Socialist Revolutionaries and Mensheviks and rallied around the Bolshevik Party, recognizing it as their leader and guide. Without these reasons, the October Revolution could not have succeeded. The Bolshevik Party organized the Soviet state. From the very first days of the victory of the Great Proletarian Revolution, Lenin and Stalin began organizing the Soviet state as a fraternal socialist union of all peoples. The peoples of Russia received from Soviet power complete liberation, such as no other people in the world had ever experienced.
Felix Edmundovich Dzerzhinsky (1877–1926).
Following the decrees on peace and land, a decree on workers' control was issued. Workers' control was established over capitalists in factories and plants, over the production, storage, purchase, and sale of all food products and raw materials. The Council of People's Commissars declared a refusal to pay all debts to foreign states. However, defeated in the capital and the country's centers, the enemies of Soviet power—landowners, capitalists, generals, and priests, along with the Mensheviks and Socialist Revolutionaries—fled to the outskirts of Russia. In the Don region, in right-bank Ukraine, in the Caucasus, in the Orenburg steppes, and in Siberia, they attempted to consolidate their position and organize a campaign against Soviet power. But their own forces were weak, and the workers and peasants did not follow them. The rebellions and conspiracies staged by the Mensheviks and Socialist Revolutionaries failed. The Red Guard and the All-Russian Extraordinary Commission for Combating Counter-Revolution (VChK), headed by F. E. Dzerzhinsky, were sufficient to suppress these plots by the Socialist Revolutionaries, Mensheviks, and their Cadets allies. The Soviet government's fight against counterrevolutionary conspiracies later became much more difficult when the Cadet and Socialist Revolutionary-Menshevik rebels began to receive direct military support from capitalist states. This constituted a military intervention by capitalist states against Soviet power and the Soviet system. The Soviets' struggle against this intervention lasted for three full years.
XIII. Military intervention. Civil war
55. The Soviets' struggle for peace. The Germans' seizure of Ukraine.
Peace with Germany. Although the war continued, the old Russian army was no longer capable of fighting, and soldiers fled to their homes. Soldiers returned home on the roofs of train cars, on the buffers and brakes of trains. Exhausted by the war, the country and the army needed a respite. The Council of People's Commissars, based on a decree adopted at the Second Congress of Soviets, appealed to all belligerent powers with a proposal to conclude a general peace. The governments of England and France, then joined by the United States of America, responded to this appeal with silence. Germany and its allies, more exhausted by the war than England and France, entered into peace negotiations with the Soviet government. Germany wanted to retain some of the lands conquered from Russia. The arrogant German generals were forced to negotiate with delegates of workers and peasants from the Land of Soviets. The Germans presented the Soviet delegation with extortionate peace terms. Since the old army had collapsed, and a new regular Red Army had not yet been created and could not be created on such short notice, the Soviets could no longer continue the war. Therefore, Lenin obliged Trotsky, who was part of the delegation, to sign a peace treaty with the Germans. But Trotsky, clearly playing into the Germans' hands and provoking them to launch a new offensive against the unarmed Soviet Union, disrupted the peace negotiations. The Germans took advantage of this, launched a new offensive, and occupied part of Soviet territory. German troops were approaching Petrograd . At Lenin's insistence, peace with the Germans was hastily concluded in the city of Brest. This was the Brest Peace Treaty. In addition to the loss of Soviet territory occupied by the Germans, they were forced to agree to other concessions to Germany. The traitor Trotsky and his henchman Bukharin did everything they could to disrupt the Brest Peace Treaty and betray the young Soviet Republic.
The Red Army, in the early days of its organization.
Lenin and Stalin, agreeing to an unfavorable peace, had no doubt that the time would come when the revolution would triumph in Germany, and Soviet power in Russia would have time to create the Red Army, grow stronger, and be able to restore what had been lost. With the conclusion of the Brest-Litovsk Peace, the Soviet government gained a respite and began to build the national economy and create and strengthen the Red Army. The Red Army was created in 1918. The Germans seized Soviet lands. Although the Brest-Litovsk Peace, concluded by the Soviet government with the Germans, extended to the entire territory of the Soviet state, including Ukraine, some Ukrainian delegates, bribed by the Germans, refused to submit to the Soviet government and concluded their own separate peace treaty with the Germans. By virtue of this treacherous treaty, Ukraine was declared not a Soviet republic, but a bourgeois republic. If the Soviets resisted, the Germans pledged to support the Ukrainian bourgeois government, then known as the Ukrainian Rada, with their troops. The German invaders took advantage of this treaty and entered Ukraine with their troops. They captured Ukraine, then the Don and Georgia. The advancing German army dispersed the Soviets along the way, hanging Bolsheviks and workers and peasants who supported Soviet power. The Red Army was still very weak at the time, but it did not cede Soviet lands to the Germans without a fight. At the head of the workers' detachments of Donetsk miners, poor rural peasants, and revolutionary sailors stood a favorite of the workers, a Lugansk mechanic, a selflessly brave Bolshevik, and one of the best disciples of Lenin and Stalin—Kliment Yefremovich Voroshilov. For a month and a half, Voroshilov's troops fought off the advancing Germans and White Cossack detachments on the Don. On the Don, the Cossacks blew up a bridge. Under a hail of bullets and shells from the White Cossacks, the Red Army soldiers built a bridge across the Don. Some worked, others fought the Cossacks. Voroshilov encouraged the soldiers, instilled confidence in his troops with his example of personal bravery, and managed to get the Red Army across the Don to Tsaritsyn (now Stalingrad). German and Austrian troops captured all of Ukraine. The Germans installed a major Ukrainian landowner, the tsarist general Skoropadsky, as hetman in Ukraine and returned the lands to the landowners and the factories to the capitalists.
Nikolai Shchors is a hero of the Ukrainian Civil War.
Labor organizations in Ukraine were banned. Bullets, gallows, and abuses at the hands of landowners, capitalists, and the German military descended upon the working class and peasants of Ukraine. The Germans confiscated livestock from peasants and emptied their barns of grain. Trains carrying Ukrainian grain, sugar, lard, meat, coal, and iron ore departed daily for Germany and Austria. The plunder and violence of the German invaders roused Ukrainian workers and peasants to struggle. Nikolai Shchors, the son of a railroad worker, became particularly famous for his courageous fight against the Germans. He fought the enemies of the Ukrainian workers and peasants as heroically as Vasily Ivanovich Chapayev, a hero of the Russian people. But the Germans did not hold out long in Ukraine. German soldiers barely fought off the rebellious Ukrainian workers and peasants. And when revolution broke out in Germany at the end of 1918, the German soldiers fled to Germany. Ukraine became Soviet again. The predatory Brest-Litovsk Treaty with the Germans was annulled by the Soviet government.
56. The Soviet Republic surrounded by intervention and counterrevolution.
Factories and plants are state property. The struggle for bread. Russia, devastated by the World War, began the socialist revolution amidst the extreme decline of the entire national economy. Manufacturers and plant owners refused to submit to workers' control. They damaged and broke machines, neglected to repair them, left factories and plants without raw materials and fuel, and sometimes closed their enterprises altogether. The Soviet government waged a decisive struggle against these enemies, who were trying to strangle the revolution in this way.
Workers' control was established in factories.
Banks, railways, and then factories and plants were taken away from the capitalists. In 1918, capitalist enterprises became the property of the Soviet state. Workers and Soviet engineers were appointed directors of factories and plants. But due to a shortage of fuel and raw materials, many factories and plants could not be immediately put into operation. The country was short of grain. The kulaks, brutal enemies of the revolution, hid grain in pits, let it rot, and sold it to speculators, all to avoid feeding the Soviet state and the Red Army. The supply of grain to Russia's worker centers from grain-producing regions was cut off by counterrevolutionaries and interventionists who rose up against Soviet power. Famine threatened to destroy the revolution.
A meeting of the Village Poor Committee in 1918.
At Lenin's call, workers created food detachments to collect surplus grain in the villages and fight the kulaks. At Lenin's suggestion, committees of the poor (kombedy) were organized in the villages. They assisted the food detachments in taking grain from the kulaks and gave the poor horses and cattle confiscated from the kulaks. The Party and the Poor Peasants' Committees also attracted the middle peasantry to an alliance and friendship with the working class and the poor. The middle peasants, seeing that the Soviet government, which had given them land, was protecting them from the landlords and defeating their enemies, began to fight for the Soviets together with the working class and the poor. The United States, England, France, and Japan began military intervention in the Land of Soviets. The foreign bourgeoisie feared that the sparks of revolutionary fire in Russia would ignite revolutions throughout the world. Foreign capitalists also could not accept the fact that they were losing the opportunity to receive enormous income from Russia on their capital invested in Russia before the revolution. In alliance with Russian landlords and the bourgeoisie, the governments of England, France, and Japan launched a civil war against the Soviet government. In the spring of 1918, Czechoslovaks, captured by the Russians during the World War, with the support of France, launched a counterrevolutionary uprising against Soviet Russia. The Socialist Revolutionaries and Mensheviks, together with the Czechoslovaks, seized part of the Volga region, the Urals, and Siberia. In the summer of 1918, the British landed troops in Arkhangelsk on the White Sea and helped the White Guards overthrow Soviet power. The Japanese landed troops in Vladivostok. All these bourgeois states that had begun the war against Soviet power were then called the Entente, meaning alliance or allies. The Entente stirred up uprisings in various cities of Soviet Russia with the help of the Cadets, Mensheviks, and Socialist Revolutionaries. The bourgeoisie bribed bandits to assassinate the leaders of the revolution. The Bolshevik Uritsky and the Bolshevik Voldarsky, a favorite orator of the Petrograd workers, were killed. In the fall of 1918, after a rally at a Moscow factory, the Socialist Revolutionaries attempted to assassinate V. I. Lenin. The Socialist Revolutionaries, together with the Bukharinites and Trotskyists, were plotting an uprising. Lenin, bleeding profusely, was taken home. For many days, Vladimir Ilyich struggled with death. All workers followed the progress of their beloved leader's illness. A sigh of relief and joy escaped them when the recovered Ilyich returned to governing the state. By this time, the Entente powers had seized the White Sea coast, the Urals, and Siberia. White Cossacks attempted to capture Tsaritsyn, a major city on the Volga, and cut off grain supplies to the center of the country. The Bolshevik Central Committee sent Comrade Stalin to defend Tsaritsyn. Here, Stalin met with Voroshilov, who had arrived with Red troops from Donbass. Day and night, without rest, Stalin worked to strengthen the Tsaritsyn front. He rooted out traitors who had infiltrated the Red Army's rear, ensured the armament and supply of the troops, and sent grain down the Volga to the workers of Moscow, Petrograd , and other cities. The White Cossacks attempted to take Tsaritsyn several times, but to no avail. Stalin and Voroshilov dealt the Cossacks blow after blow and defended this important city on the Volga. Along with Tsaritsyn, Astrakhan, where Comrade Kirov led the Red Army, also fought the Whites. The Whites never managed to capture Astrakhan. Civil war in Transcaucasia and Central Asia. Germany helped the Mensheviks, enemies of the Georgian people, gain a foothold in Georgia. The Georgian Mensheviks came to power through bloodshed. They executed many workers and peasants fighting for Soviet power. Armenian workers and peasants also failed to immediately free themselves from bourgeois oppression. In Armenia, the Entente supported the enemies of the Armenian people, the Dashnaks.
The execution of 26 Baku Bolshevik commissars in 1918.
The Turks intended to seize Baku in Azerbaijan, with its large oil industry. In 1918, Soviet power reigned in Baku. The Baku Soviet was led by the Bolshevik Stepan Shaumyan and other old Bolsheviks—friends and disciples of Comrade Stalin. Baku nationalists, ostensibly to save the city from the Turks, invited British troops to Baku in the summer of 1918. Having occupied the city, the British arrested Shaumyan, Azizbekov, Japaridze, and other Baku commissars—26 in all—taken them to Turkmenistan, and executed them there. In Turkmenistan, the British destroyed Soviet power and installed a wholly obedient government of White Guards—the Socialist Revolutionaries and Mensheviks. In Khiva and Bukhara, the British helped the enemies of the Uzbek people—the Khan of Khiva and the Emir of Bukharan—retain power.
57. Revolution in Western Europe
. The November Revolution in Germany. The Great Proletarian Revolution in Russia divided the world into two camps. On one-sixth of the globe, in Russia, the power of the proletariat—the builder of socialism—was strengthened. Soviet Russia, like a beacon, illuminated the path to the victory of socialism for workers in capitalist countries. The first Western European workers to rise up were the German proletarians. Germany's defeat in the World War accelerated open mass rebellion. In November 1918, an uprising broke out in German cities, in workers' centers, and in the army and navy on ships. XIV. Transition to Peaceful Work to Rebuild the Country's Economy
60. Rebuilding the National Economy. The Creation of the USSR:
Lenin's Plan for Escape from Devastation. The world war and the civil war imposed by the Entente and counterrevolutionaries had brought the country to utter ruin. Many factories and plants were idle: there was no fuel or raw materials, broken locomotives and mangled carriages littered the railroad tracks. Bridges and railroad tracks had been blown up in many places by the Whites and had to be rebuilt. Industry produced five times less goods than before the war. Peasant fields were poorly cultivated. Much livestock had been taken away during the Tsarist war. Many were killed during the Civil War. Agriculture yielded half as much food as in 1914. There was famine in the country. Private trade was prohibited during the Civil War. Peasants, accustomed to trade, expressed discontent at this time. The bourgeoisie and kulaks, taking advantage of this discontent, roused peasants in several places to revolt against Soviet rule. The Party and the Soviet government decided to implement a number of measures to improve the country's economy. Vladimir Ilyich proposed the following plan in 1921. During the Civil War, peasants donated all their surplus grain to industry, workers, and the Red Army. Workers and peasants had formed a military alliance against landowners and factory owners. Now they needed an alliance to restore the economy and build socialism. Let the peasants not give all their surplus to the state, but pay a precisely defined tax in kind. They could dispose of their remaining products as they wish. To this end, private trade must be permitted. Private industrialists and merchants should be allowed to open small businesses and conduct trade. For the time being, let private industrialists and merchants produce and trade goods. "We will quickly grow stronger and displace private capital. And the time will come when we will completely eliminate the remnants of capitalists and kulaks in our country," Lenin said. Lenin's plan was adopted. It was called the New Economic Policy (NEP). To speed up economic recovery, the Communist Party, as it had during the Civil War, held subbotniks (workdays) for the first time. All workers participated. They worked for free for the benefit of their homeland. Lenin's plan proved successful. Within three to four years, the country's economy was firmly on its feet: factories and plants began operating, and the railways improved. Agriculture also boomed. Peasants brought grain, meat, and eggs to the markets. They began sowing beets and flax, and increased cotton cultivation. Sugar refineries and textile factories began operating across the country. Workers and peasants now had access to grain, sugar, fabrics, and many other goods. Many state-owned and cooperative stores opened. These enterprises began to displace private traders. Vladimir Ilyich Lenin—that mountain eagle, as Stalin called him—had a far-reaching vision. He said that workers and peasants could easily overcome devastation and lead happy lives. They would have to have factories within their own economy where machines were made, and these machines would have to run on electricity. The entire country, Lenin said more than once, needed to be covered with a network of power plants. A plan for the country's electrification was developed. At Lenin's suggestion, construction began on the first large water-powered electric power station on the Volkhov River, near Leningrad. In 1926, after Lenin's death, the station was completed and provided electricity to Leningrad's factories and plants. This helped restore Leningrad's vital industry. Power stations were also built in other parts of the country: in the Urals, Ukraine, and Transcaucasia. The end of the Japanese intervention. While the entire Soviet Union was rebuilding its economy, our rich land—the Far East—had been under Japanese control since 1918. But in 1922, the Red Army, together with Siberian partisans, ended the war here too and liberated the entire Far East from Japanese bandits and White Guards. Red soldiers won glorious victories in battles against the White and Japanese forces near Spassk and Volochayevka. Near the village of Volochayevka, the White Guards erected strong barbed wire entanglements. In winter, in the bitter cold, naked and almost barefoot, Red soldiers marched to the entanglements, tearing the wire with their bare hands, cutting it with sabers. The fortifications were taken. The Whites and Japanese fled.
Sergei Lazo—a hero of the civil war in the Far East. In 1920, Comrade Lazo was burned alive in the firebox of a locomotive by Japanese invaders.
In October 1922, the Red Army liberated Vladivostok. The Japanese yoke over the Far East was thrown off. But the workers of Siberia and the Far East will long remember the violence and looting perpetrated by the Japanese army. The workers and peasants will never forget how the Japanese burned Red partisans alive in the fireboxes of locomotives. Thus died the hero Sergei Lazo for the liberation of the Far East. The creation of the USSR. Now the entire country was cleared of White troops and invaders. It was necessary to protect the country from further armed attacks by bourgeois countries. It was necessary to revive the economy and build socialism. It was necessary to assist all the peoples of the Land of Soviets in raising their national culture. To achieve all this, it was necessary to create a unified union state. To this end, in 1922, at the suggestion of Lenin and Stalin, delegates from the union republics gathered in Moscow for the First All-Union Congress of Soviets and formed a voluntary state association of peoples, a union state called the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR). Initially, the USSR united several Soviet republics: the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic (RSFSR), with its capital Moscow; the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic (USSR), with its capital initially in Kharkov and later in Kiev; and the Byelorussian Soviet Socialist Republic (BSSR), with its capital Minsk. The Transcaucasian Soviet Socialist Republics—Azerbaijan, Georgia, and Armenia—formed a single union—the Transcaucasian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic (TSFSR), with its capital Tbilisi. A little later, three independent Soviet republics were established in Central Asia: Uzbekistan, with its capital in Tashkent; Turkmenistan, with its capital in Ashgabat; and Tajikistan, with its capital in Stalinabad. These republics also became part of the USSR.
V. I. Lenin and I. V. Stalin in Gorki during V. I. Lenin's illness.
The peoples of the USSR began to live as a close-knit family. Many nationalities, dying out, oppressed, and illiterate under tsarism, were now revived and began to build socialism in a fraternal union of peoples. The development of national culture took rapid strides in all the republics. Many schools, universities, and libraries were opened, theaters were built, and many books began to be printed in national languages. The peoples of the USSR, previously unwritten, received their own alphabet. The culture of the peoples flourished.
61. Lenin died, but his work lives on

Working people all over the world lost their leader, who prepared and carried out the proletarian revolution, saving it from countless enemies in difficult years. A man greater than anyone had done for humanity died. Deepest sorrow gripped millions of working people. In the bitter January frosts, lines of Moscow workers walked to bid farewell to the ashes of their brilliant leader. They were overcome with deep sorrow and a firm resolve to follow the path shown by Lenin.
Moscow workers walk to bid farewell to the ashes of V. I. Lenin in the Column Hall of the House of Unions.

XV. Five-Year Plans of Socialism and the Great Patriotic War
62. Socialist Industry and Collective Farms in Agriculture (Kolkhozes)
Construction of Socialist Industry. The old factories and plants that were put into operation were very backward and had outdated machinery. There were few of them, and they produced very few goods needed by the country. Little pig iron was smelted. Little oil and coal were mined. Many goods were not produced at all. They had to be imported from abroad.
Vyacheslav Mikhailovich Molotov.
In 1925, at the 14th Party Congress, Comrade Stalin, on the Party's instructions, declared that we must transform our agricultural country into an industrial one in the shortest possible time. To do this, we must build many new factories, plants, and power plants; and refurbish all the old plants in accordance with the latest scientific and technological advances. We must build tractors, combines, automobiles, new machine tools for factories, and airplanes. We must create many well-trained workers and specialists. We must catch up with and surpass the most advanced capitalist countries, "otherwise they will crush us." This is called industrialization.
Grigory Konstantinovich Ordzhonikidze (1886–1937).
But this plan for building socialism in our country was opposed by traitors within the party at the time—Trotsky, Zinoviev, and Kamenev. They strove by every means to disrupt the construction of socialist industry. They claimed that it was impossible to build a socialist society in the USSR, that workers and peasants could not do without capitalists and kulaks. The foreign bourgeoisie exploited their struggle against the party to slander the Soviet Union and fight it. They bribed some of the old specialists and the remnants of the Mensheviks and Socialist Revolutionaries, creating counterrevolutionary groups of saboteurs to disrupt the USSR's growing industry. But the Trotskyists continued their struggle against the party and the people. The party expelled the Trotskyists from its ranks. Trotsky was expelled from the Soviet Union by the people, and he openly went into the service of the bourgeoisie.

The workers of the Union enthusiastically took up this great construction project, displaying examples of labor heroism. In the Soviet Union, labor became a matter of honor and glory, a matter of valor and heroism. Intense work continued day and night at construction sites.
Blast furnaces of the Kuznetsk Metallurgical Plant.
Socialist competition unfolded in factories, plants, and railways. 64. The New Constitution of the USSR
How our state is built. The Great Proletarian Revolution destroyed and abolished the hated tsarist monarchy and its laws that kept workers and peasants in chains. Soviet republics emerged and were strengthened in Ukraine, Belarus, Central Asia, and Transcaucasia. Through the combined efforts of all these Soviet republics, all enemies were finally defeated. The liberated peoples began to rebuild their war-torn economies. In 1922, under the leadership of the Bolshevik Party, they created the great Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. The USSR initially included four union republics, later joined by three more. Nowhere in the world has there been, or continues to be, such friendship and mutual trust among peoples as in the USSR. In 1924, the free peoples of the USSR adopted the first Constitution of the USSR (the Basic Law of the State). In it, they enshrined the country's victories. Much time has passed since then—industry has been built and expanded enormously, collective and state farms have been established, culture has flourished, the remnants of landowners, capitalists, and kulaks have been uprooted and destroyed, the exploitation of workers and oppression of people have been abolished. But in our country, enemies of the Soviet people, enemies of the USSR, still remained. It was they—the friends of Trotsky, Zinoviev, and Kamenev, and with them Rykov and Bukharin—who organized a gang of murderers, saboteurs, and spies in the USSR. It was they who viciously murdered Sergei Mironovich Kirov, a Bolshevik loyal to the people. They also brought about the death of the great Russian writer Maxim Gorky. They assassinated V. V. Kuibyshev and V. R. Menzhinsky. Trotskyists and Rykovites did whatever they could: sabotaged machinery in factories and plants, blew up mines and railway bridges, and caused train derailments. They dreamed of destroying state farms, of destroying our powerful collective farm economy. They dreamed of handing over our rich Soviet Ukraine to the Germans and the Far East to the Japanese. They dreamed of war and the military defeat of the USSR. Soviet power mercilessly and promptly eliminated the enemies of the Soviet people. Socialism triumphed in the USSR.
In 1936, a commission led by I. V. Stalin drafted a new Constitution of the USSR. It was submitted for broad public debate and then approved by the highest governing body of the Union—the All-Union Congress of Soviets. The day the Constitution was approved, December 5, was declared a national holiday. The Constitution enshrines the most important achievements of the Soviet Union during its 19 years of existence. The previous Constitution stated that our republic was called socialist because the working class held power and strove to build socialism. The new Constitution calls our state a socialist state of workers and peasants because socialism had already been largely built in the USSR. In the USSR, all power belongs to the workers of the city and village—the Soviets of Workers' Deputies. The land, its mineral wealth, factories, mines, plants, railways, large buildings, and state farms (state farms) are the property of the state and the common property of the people. Alongside state ownership, there is cooperative and collective farm ownership, the property of individual collective farms, and cooperative associations. The Constitution stipulates that small-scale farming by artisans and individual peasants is also permitted in the USSR, but only on the condition that such artisans or individual peasants work independently and do not exploit the labor of others. Our state achieved all this because it abolished the landowners and capitalists, destroyed the kulaks, and abolished the exploitation of man by man. In the USSR, all people capable of labor must work. "He who does not work, neither shall he eat." The USSR is a voluntary and friendly association of equal peoples. "And this friendship is a great thing: as long as it exists," said Stalin, "the peoples of our country will be free and invincible." Currently, the USSR is a voluntary association of 16 equal union republics. The USSR includes: the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic, the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic, the Byelorussian Soviet Socialist Republic, the Uzbek Soviet Socialist Republic, the Kazakh Soviet Socialist Republic, the Georgian Soviet Socialist Republic, the Azerbaijan Soviet Socialist Republic, the Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic, the Moldavian Soviet Socialist Republic, the Latvian Soviet Socialist Republic, the Kirghiz Soviet Socialist Republic, the Tajik Soviet Socialist Republic, the Armenian Soviet Socialist Republic, the Turkmen Soviet Socialist Republic, the Estonian Soviet Socialist Republic, and the Karelo-Finnish Soviet Socialist Republic.
The highest body of state power in the USSR is the Supreme Soviet of the USSR. Only the Supreme Soviet has the right to issue laws. It forms the government of the USSR — the Council of Ministers of the USSR. At the local level, the organs of power everywhere are the councils of workers' deputies. All local councils, as well as the supreme councils of the union and autonomous republics, as well as the Supreme Soviet of the USSR, are elected by citizens of the USSR on the basis of universal, equal, and direct suffrage by secret ballot. All citizens of the USSR, both men and women, who have reached the age of 18, regardless of race, nationality, religion, educational qualifications, social origin, property status, or past activities, have the right to participate in the elections of deputies, with the exception of the insane and individuals convicted by a court with deprivation of voting rights. Citizens who have reached the age of 23 may be elected to the Supreme Soviet of the USSR. Such elections are called universal. All citizens have equal rights in elections. Citizens of our country elect deputies to all bodies of government by personal vote. Such elections are called direct elections. Voting in elections is secret; every citizen votes for the person they wish to elect to the council. Citizens of the USSR have the right to work, rest, education, and financial security in old age. These rights are guaranteed by our state. In a socialist country, there is no unemployment, which affects millions of workers in capitalist countries. Thousands of rest homes and sanatoriums are open to workers. Every year, all workers and employees of the USSR are granted vacation. In the USSR, all workers can study and receive an education. The state provides scholarships to many students. In the USSR, every person is cared for from birth to old age. Nurseries and kindergartens are organized for children. The elderly and sick are provided with state assistance. All citizens of the USSR are guaranteed freedom of speech, press, assembly, and street demonstrations. But in addition to rights, every citizen of the USSR also has responsibilities to the state. All citizens are obliged to strictly comply with the laws of the Soviet Union, maintain discipline, work honestly, and protect and strengthen socialist property. Anyone who encroaches on socialist property is an enemy of the peoples of the USSR. Defending the Fatherland from any and all enemies of the USSR is the highest duty of a citizen of the USSR. If anyone goes over to the enemy's side or reveals the USSR's military secrets to the enemy, he will betray his homeland, his people, and will be punished as an enemy of the USSR.
